awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Electrochemical Separation Device for Co-Ni Recovery from Li-ion Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project includes providing a high-throughput system for recycling critical metals like cobalt to reduce the conventional energy-intensive mining and refining processes used to produce materials for manufacturing today. Most importantly, this project will help secure a supply of critical materials, reducing the United States’ reliance on foreign supply chains and guaranteeing a secondary source of battery materials. A new, domestic supply will also reduce the social and human health impacts associated with artisanal mining, and significantly reduce the environmental impact of batteries and electric vehicles.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to (1) validate novel electro-extraction nanotechnology based separations technology in the battery recycling and cobalt mining space, and (2) validate a new, value-added product (a battery cathode precursor material) for this rapidly growing market, rendering the conventional refining stages unnecessary.   The proposed electroextraction process utilizes flow-through water electrolysis to produce high local concentrations of hydroxide to precipitate transition metals as metal hydroxides.  This understanding will allow tuning the device operating conditions for metal or mixed-metal specific precipitation, for example, the precipitation of Ni-Mn-Co hydroxides at battery stoichiometries or highly selective precipitation of individual metals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Nth Cycle’s NSF SBIR Phase II project helped advance a sustainable, energy-efficient metal processing technology for low-cost, environmentally-friendly domestic refining of black mass from Li-ion batteries. Here, the bench- and pilot- scale technology was validated by demonstrating Nth Cycle’s novel electroextraction technology could process spent batteries into added-value battery-grade products for the Li-ion battery manufacturing supply chain. Specifically, the tasks completed for the NSF SBIR Phase II Award achieved multiple milestones: 1) development of a flexible electroextraction process to rationally produce stoichiometric nickel-manganese-cobalt (NMC) precursor cathode active materials (pCAM), 2) validation of Nth Cycle’s NMC pCAM in coin and pouch Li-ion battery cells demonstrating capacity and cycling performance on par with Li-ion batteries produced from virgin materials, and 3) preliminary evaluation of electroextraction for selective nickel recovery from domestic nickel ore concentrates.  In addition to hitting all technology milestones, a system-level analysis was also completed, indicating electroextraction has potential to significantly reduce water use, chemical consumable use, GHG emissions, and waste production as compared to classical centralized metallurgical methods.

These outcomes significantly reduce the technical risk while helping to identify the next steps towards commercialization. In addition, the NSF support during this project helped solidify our value proposition in this growing market space, indicating that our main differentiators are (1) our clean operations that allow us to secure permits in under 6 months, and (2) our modularity that allows for on-site production and rapid deployment in under 12 months. This technology will not only help mitigate the low incentive to recycle here in the U.S. by providing a rapidly deployable system for li-ion battery refining, but it will also: (1) reduce the need for mining in politically unstable regions thus decreasing national security risk, (2) lower demand for primary battery materials and reducing the environmental impact (3) reduce manufacturing costs with fewer refining steps, and most importantly, (4) significantly reduce the GHG emissions from this industry by utilizing secondary materials instead of primary materials for manufacturing.


Last Modified: 12/04/2024
Modified by: Megan P O'connor
